questions.text: Which of the following paraneoplastic syndromes is NOT commonly associated with small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC)?
questions.explanation:
Lung Cancer Type

Paraneoplastic Syndromes

Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC)
  • Hyponatremia (SIADH) (Option A ruled out)
  • Ectopic ACTH Production (Cushing-like syndrome) (Option D ruled out)
  • Eaton-Lambert Syndrome (common) (Option B ruled out)
  • Hypertrophic Osteoarthropathy
  • Peripheral Neuropathy, Cerebellar Degeneration
  • Thrombotic Events (occasionally)

Adenocarcinoma

  
  • Hypertrophic Osteoarthropathy (1-10% of cases)
  • Neurological and Muscular Syndromes (rarely)

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)
  • Hypercalcemia (frequent due to PTHrP)
  • Thrombotic Events (e.g., Trousseau’s syndrome)
  • Peripheral and central neuropathies

Common Across Lung Cancers
  • Hematologic Syndromes (e.g., Thrombotic Events, Leukemoid reactions, Pure red cell aplasia)
  • Neurological and Muscular Syndromes (e.g., Peripheral Neuropathy, Cerebellar Degeneration)
  • Nonbacterial thrombotic (marantic) endocarditis (NBTE)
  • Carcinoid syndrome
  • Gynecomastia
  • Acanthosis nigricans
  • Erythema gyratum repens
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hypouricemia

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a history of choking followed by intermittent coughing and wheezing. The X-ray is as follows. What is the most appropriate investigation for diagnosis and intervention?

A 55 y/o male with a persistent cough and occasional chest discomfort has a chest X-ray showing a 2.5 cm peripheral, sharply demarcated, lobulated mass with a “popcorn” appearance. No smoking history. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
PULMONARY HAMARTOMA

Characteristics
  • Most frequent benign tumour of the lung.
  • Consist of normal tissue elements containing mesothelial and endothelial elements in an abnormal location; overgrowth of cartilage.

Age & Sex
  • 40 to 60 years.
  • More common in males.

Location
  • Usually peripheral and slow-growing.

Imaging Findings
  • CXR shows a 2 to 3-cm mass that is sharply demarcated and lobulated;
    • Usually not calcified
    • “Popcorn” appearance is characteristic

Treatment

Excision of the lesion

Related Conditions

Cystic adenomatoid malformation in infants may represent adenomatous hamartomas (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 45 y/o male with a 3-month history of cough, hemoptysis, and wheezing has a CXR showing a central mass obstructing the right bronchus. Biopsy reveals a low-grade malignant tumour diagnosed as bronchial adenoma. Which of the following is NOT a type of bronchial adenoma?
questions.explanation:
BRONCHIAL ADENOMA

Definition

Tumours arising from bronchial epithelium or glands are less aggressive than typical lung cancers.

Types
  • Carcinoids (85%): Low-grade, typical and atypical variants. (Option B ruled out)
  • Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (ACC): Slow-growing, 10% of adenomas. (Option A ruled out)
  • Mucous Gland Adenomas: Benign, arise from mucous glands.
  • Mucoepidermoid Carcinomas: 1-5% of adenomas, varying malignancy. (Option D ruled out)

Symptoms
  • Central Lesions: Dyspnea, stridor, wheezing, cough, hemoptysis, recurrent infections.
  • Peripheral Lesions: Often asymptomatic, may be discovered incidentally.

Diagnostic Tests
  • Chest X-ray: Detects nodules or masses, central lesions best seen with an oblique view
  • CT Scan: Assesses tumor size, location, lymph node spread
  • Bronchoscopy: Visualizes airways, allows biopsy
  • MRI: Used when CT is unclear
  • Octreotide Nuclear Scan: Detects carcinoid tumors, metastasis sites
  • CT-Guided Fine-Needle Aspiration: For peripheral nodules

Treatment
  • Surgical Resection: Main treatment
  • Bronchoscopic Surgery: For small tumours; higher bleeding risk.
  • Open Lung Surgery/VATS: Preferred for complete removal, maximal parenchymal preservation
  • Laser Ablation: Not recommended as primary treatment, used for recurrent tumours.

Prognosis

The 5-year survival rate is 96% following complete surgical resection.

questions.text: A 65-y/o male, who worked for 30 years in shipbuilding, presents with a 6-month h/o progressive shortness of breath, chest pain, and significant weight loss. A CXR reveals a pleural effusion and a subsequent pleural biopsy confirms the diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma. Which subtype of malignant mesothelioma is most likely to be associated with a better prognosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA

About
  • Highly aggressive malignancy originating from pleural mesothelial cells, strongly linked to asbestos.
  • The most common primary pleural tumor.

Latency Period

15–40 years after asbestos exposure.

Risk Factors
  • Male predominance (2:1);
  • Most common after age 40.
  • Asbestos exposure (occupational, familial): Commonly in industries like shipbuilding, brake pad manufacturing, and other asbestos-related manufacturing processes.
  • Secondary Exposure: Family members of workers exposed their clothes and belongings.

Types of Asbestos
  • Serpentine fibres (less likely to cause mesothelioma)
  • Amphibole fibres (higher risk, especially crocidolite).

Histologic Subtypes
  • Epithelial: Better prognosis
  • Sarcomatoid: More aggressive (Option A ruled out)
  • Mixed: Combination of both; Aggressive (Option C & D ruled out)

Symptoms
  • Dyspnea, chest pain, pleural effusion in over 90% of cases, weight loss, fever.
  • Onset: Insidious, leading to late-stage diagnosis in most patients.

questions.text: A 65 y/o male with a 30-year history in brake pad manufacturing presents with dyspnea, chest discomfort, and cough. Imaging shows pleural thickening and nodules. Biopsy confirms early-stage malignant mesothelioma. Which IHC markers and treatments are most consistent with this diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive CEA, negative vimentin, treated with radiation therapy alone

options.label: B
options.text: Negative CEA, positive vimentin, treated with Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD) combined with chemotherapy

options.label: C
options.text: Positive CEA, negative cytokeratins, treated with chemotherapy only

options.label: D
options.text: Negative vimentin, positive cytokeratins, treated with Extrapleural Pneumonectomy (EPP) alone

questions.correct_answer: B. Negative CEA, positive vimentin, treated with Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD) combined with chemotherapy
questions.explanation:
MALIGNANT MESOTHELIOMA

About
  • Highly aggressive malignancy originating from pleural mesothelial cells, strongly linked to asbestos.
  • The most common primary pleural tumour.

Diagnosis
  • Imaging:
    • CXR, CT, MRI, FDG-PET: Assess tumour invasion and metastasis
    • ECG: Checks for cardiac involvement
  • Biopsy: Pleural Biopsy: Via thoracoscopy, thoracentesis, or open techniques.
  • Immunhistochemistry findings:

Diagnosis

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Negative

Positive

(Options A & C ruled out)

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

(Option D ruled out)

Low Molecular Weight Cytokines

Positive

Negative

Electron Microscopy

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx
 
  • Staging: Based on tumour invasion (T), lymph node involvement (N), and metastasis (M).

Treatment

Multimodality Therapy:

  • Early-stage: Surgery (EPP or EPD) with cisplatin-based chemotherapy and radiotherapy.
  • Advanced Disease: Chemotherapy may extend survival but not cure.
  • Palliative Care: Pleural catheters, pleurodesis.

Surgical Options:

  • Extrapleural Pneumonectomy (EPP): Complete lung resection; higher risk but more extensive.
  • Extended Pleurectomy and Decortication (EPD): Lung-preserving, safer, preferred in many centres.

Prognosis

Median survival is 24–36 months depending on stage and treatment.

Diagnosis

Mesothelioma

Adenocarcinoma

Carcinoembryonic Antigen (CEA)

Negative

Positive

(Options A & C ruled out)

Vimentin

Positive

Negative

(Option D ruled out)

Low Molecular Weight Cytokines

Positive

Negative

Electron Microscopy

Long, sinuous villi

Short, straight villi with fuzzy glycocalyx

questions.text: What is the most common type of lung carcinoma?

A 60-year-old male, with a 40-year history of smoking, presents with a persistent cough, hoarseness, and recent onset of facial swelling and distended neck veins. Imaging reveals a mass in the central region of the right lung. Based on the location and clinical features, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Type of Lung Cancer

Key Features

Tumor Location

Adenocarcinoma

(Option A ruled out)
  • Most common histologic type (45% of lung cancers).
  • Early metastasis, CNS involvement, mucin production, glandular differentiation

Peripheral

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)
  • Associated with smoking (90% of cases).
  • Keratinization, intercellular bridges, central necrosis & cavitation.

Central

Large Cell Carcinoma (Option C ruled out)
  • Highly aggressive
  • Undifferentiated, lacks specific features.
  • Slow-growing, but highly vascular.

Peripheral

Small Cell Neuroendocrine Tumors
  • Highly aggressive
  • Early metastasis to lymph node,
  • Neuroendocrine origin

Central

Typical/Atypical Carcinoids
  • Typical Carcinoids- Indolent growth
  • Atypical Carcinoids- Aggressive growth

Varies

Apical (Pancoast's Tumors) (Option D ruled out)
  • Invades brachial plexus
  • Causes severe localized pain.
  • Pancoast’s syndrome

Apical (Upper Lung)

questions.text: What is the most common site of metastasis for lung cancer?

A 65 y/o woman presents to the emergency with a sudden onset of shortness of breath, chest pain, and hypotension. She is diagnosed with a massive pulmonary embolism. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

A 65 y/o male with a 35-pack-year smoking history presents with worsening dyspnea, cough, and weight loss. A CT shows a 6.5 cm right upper lobe mass invading the chest wall, with ipsilateral mediastinal lymph node involvement and liver metastasis as seen on the PET scan. What is the TNM stage of his lung cancer?
questions.explanation:
AJCC 8TH EDITION OF TNM STAGING OF LUNG CARCINOMA

PRIMARY TUMOR (T)

T1

T1a(mi)

Minimally invasive carcinoma

T1a

≤ 1 cm

T1b

1 - 2 cm

T1c

2 - 3 cm

T2
  • Involvement of the main bronchus with the involvement of carina
  • Involvement of visceral pleura
  • Association with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis
 

T2a

3 - ≤4 cm

T2b

4 - ≤5 cm

T3

  
  • > 5 - ≤7 cm OR
  • Direct invasion of Chest wall, Phrenic nerve, Pericardium OR
  • Satellite nodules in the same lobe

T4

  
  • > 7 cm in greatest dimension OR
  • Any tumour with invasion of the mediastinum, diaphragm, heart, great vessels, recurrent laryngeal nerve, carina, trachea, oesophagus, spine OR
  • Separate tumours in different lobes of the ipsilateral lung.

LYMPH NODE (N)

N1

Ipsilateral peribronchial and/or hilar nodes and intrapulmonary nodes

N2

Ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal nodes

N3

Contralateral mediastinal or hilar; ipsilateral/contralateral scalene/supraclavicular

DISTANT METASTASIS (M)

M1

Distant metastasis
 

M1a

Tumor in contralateral lung or pleural/pericardial nodule/malignant effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasis, including single non-regional lymph node

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

questions.text: A 65 y/o male with a confirmed diagnosis of stage IIIB non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) is being evaluated for treatment options. His disease is localized with significant mediastinal lymph node involvement, and he has a good performance status. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgical resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Chemoradiation followed by maintenance immunotherapy
questions.explanation:
Stage IA:
  • Surgical resection only.
  • No chemotherapy.

Stage IB:


 
  • Surgical resection
  • Adjuvant chemotherapy if the tumour is greater than 4 cm. (Option A ruled out )

Stage IIA & IIB:

Surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy; lobectomy is preferred.

Stage IIIA (minimal N2 involvement):

Chemoradiation or surgery followed by adjuvant chemotherapy.

Stage IIIB:

Combined chemoradiation followed by maintenance immunotherapy for 1 year.

Stage IV:

Systemic therapy with palliative radiation (Option C ruled out) including targeted therapy or immunotherapy based on mutation status.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of smoking presents with a central lung mass, weight loss, and a new diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). Which of the following is a common clinical presentation associated with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung due to its typical location?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Adenocarcinoma

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

Characteristics
  • Malignant epithelial tumours with glandular differentiation or mucin production.
  • Includes acinar, papillary, lepidic (bronchioloalveolar), and solid with mucin patterns, or a combination of these.
  • Malignant epithelial tumour showing keratinization and/or intercellular bridges.
  • Undergoes central necrosis and cavitation

Prevalence

The most frequent lung cancer type, accounting for approximately 45% of cases.

Occurs in approximately 30% of lung cancer patients; over 90% are cigarette smokers.

Clinical features

Clubbing, Acanthosis nigricans, thrombophlebitis, scar.

Can present as Pancoast tumor, hypercalcemia.

Location

Predominantly peripheral (75% of cases).

Centrally located and tend to expand against the bronchus, causing extrinsic compression.

Metastasis

Tends to metastasize earlier and more frequently to the central nervous system compared to SCC.

Tends to metastasize later than adenocarcinoma.

Management

Management involves anatomic resection for solitary tumours and a combination of surgical resection, ablation, and radiation for multifocal cases.

Anatomical resection with a combination of chemoradiotherapy.

questions.text: A 62- y/o man with a history of heavy smoking is diagnosed with a central lung mass. He is also noted to have severe hypercalcemia and is receiving chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: SCLC is less aggressive than large cell carcinoma

options.label: B
options.text: Oat cells are seen in Large cell carcinoma

options.label: C
options.text: SCLC is strongly linked to smoking and can cause SIADH

options.label: D
options.text: Large cell carcinoma usually presents in central lung areas

questions.correct_answer: C. SCLC is strongly linked to smoking and can cause SIADH
questions.explanation:
Small cell carcinoma

Large cell carcinoma

Histology

Small, oval-shaped cells,

High nucleus-to-cytoplasm ratio, scant cytoplasm; often contains "oat cells"(Option B ruled out).

Large cells with abundant cytoplasm, and prominent nucleoli.

Growth

Highly aggressive, rapid growth, early spread

(Option A ruled out).

Less aggressive than SCLC, but still fast-growing.

Aetiology

Strongly associated with smoking.

Significantly associated with smoking

Location

Central lung areas

Peripheral lung areas(Option D ruled out)

Treatment

Highly responsive to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

Moderate response to treatment often requires surgery.

Prognosis

Poor, due to early metastasis.

Better than SCLC but still poor compared to other NSCLC types.

Associated conditions

Paraneoplastic syndromes, SIADH, Cushing’s. (Option C)

Rarely associated with paraneoplastic syndromes.

questions.text: A 72 y/o woman presents with severe shoulder pain and noticeable ptosis. Imaging reveals a mass at the apex of the lung, involving the upper ribs and vertebrae. Horner’s syndrome is observed. Which imaging modalities are most suitable for the evaluation of this condition?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ SRB’s Manual of Surgery. 6th edition. Pg.1112 Bailey and Love Short manual of surgery, pg no 1986 Schwartz 11th edition , pg no 680,698
  • ↳ SRB’s Manual of Surgery. 6th edition. Pg.1112
  • ↳ Bailey and Love Short manual of surgery, pg no 1986
  • ↳ Schwartz 11th edition , pg no 680,698

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding cardiac tumours is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Angiosarcomas are the most common benign primary cardiac tumours.

options.label: B
options.text: Nearly 90% of primary cardiac tumours are malignant.

options.label: C
options.text: Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumours in adults.

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiac myocytes have high proliferative activity, contributing to the formation of cardiac tumours.

questions.correct_answer: C. Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumours in adults.
questions.explanation:
Tumour Type

Description

Myxoma

The most common primary cardiac tumour- accounts for over 50% of cases.

Rhabdomyoma

Most common in infants and children, often linked to tuberous sclerosis.

Angiosarcoma (Option A)

The most common malignant primary cardiac tumour.

questions.text: A 55 y/o female presents with symptoms of shortness of breath, occasional dizziness, and a recent episode of fever and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the left atrium and is diagnosed with atrial myxoma. Which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The majority of atrial myxomas arise from the right atrium.

options.label: B
options.text: Atrial myxomas are more common in males, around 3rd decade of life.

options.label: C
options.text: Atrial myxomas can cause systemic emboli and obstruction of blood flow.

options.label: D
options.text: The genetic cause of atrial myxomas is always linked to an autosomal recessive pattern.

questions.correct_answer: C. Atrial myxomas can cause systemic emboli and obstruction of blood flow.

questions.text: A 14 y/o boy presents with a chest wall deformity characterized by a protruding sternum, resulting in a convex appearance of the chest. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic, and his chest wall growth is nearing completion. Which of the following statements about the management of this condition is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The Nuss procedure is the preferred surgical approach.

options.label: B
options.text: Non-surgical bracing is effective in correcting pectus carinatum

options.label: C
options.text: The modified Ravitch procedure is exclusively used for treating the Pigeon chest.

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical intervention for pectus carinatum is typically recommended for cosmetic reasons.

questions.correct_answer: D. Surgical intervention for pectus carinatum is typically recommended for cosmetic reasons.

questions.text: The thoracic duct, the largest lymphatic vessel in the body, passes through the posterior mediastinum. Which of the following anatomical triangles is the key area used for locating and managing the thoracic duct?

A 48 y/o female presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, difficulty speaking, and drooping eyelids that worsen with physical activity. Imaging reveals a mass in the anterior mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely paraneoplastic syndrome associated with her condition?

A 55 y/o male presents with a persistent cough and dyspnea on exertion. A chest x-ray reveals an anterior mediastinal mass with tracheal deviation. What is the next best step in evaluating this patient for a potential thymoma?

A 63 y/o female is diagnosed with a Stage III thymoma and presents with symptoms of myasthenia gravis. The tumour appears to have invaded the superior vena cava and pericardium. What is the most appropriate treatment plan for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy as a primary treatment without surgery

questions.explanation:
Masaoka-Koga Staging System

Stage I

The tumour is completely encapsulated, meaning it is confined within the thymus gland and has not spread beyond its capsule.

Stage II

The tumour has spread beyond the capsule of the thymus.

Microscopic or macroscopic invasion into the surrounding fatty tissue or mediastinal pleura.

Stage III

The tumour has spread to adjacent organs in the chest, such as the pericardium, the lungs, or the great vessels (aorta, vena cava, pulmonary artery).

Stage IV

The tumour has spread to distant sites in the body.

  • Stage IVa: Spread to the pericardium or pleura
  • Stage IVb: Spread to distant organs through the bloodstream or lymphatic system.

questions.text: A 48 y/o man with a history of pulmonary TB presents with progressive shortness of breath, facial swelling, and difficulty swallowing. His chest X-ray shows an abnormal shadow in the mediastinum. A CT scan reveals extensive fibrotic tissue compressing the SVC and oesophagus. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 72-year-old male with COPD presents with sudden severe shortness of breath and right-sided chest pain. On examination, he is cyanotic, in respiratory distress, and has diminished breath sounds on the right side. A CXR shows a large air collection in the right pleural space. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Primary Spontaneous

Pneumothorax (PSP)

Secondary Spontaneous

Pneumothorax (SSP)

About

  
  • Occurs without underlying lung disease. (Option A)
  • Typically affects young individuals (under 35 years)
  • It arises from the rupture of small blebs or cysts on the lung surface, leading to air entering the pleural space.

.
  • Occurs in individuals with existing lung pathology.
  • More common in older adults (typically over 45 years).
  • Recurrence rates are higher compared to PSP, with up to 80% of patients experiencing additional episodes

Risk Factors
  • Male sex
  • Tall and thin body type
  • Smoking
  • Family history of pneumothorax
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Lung cancer
  • Other lung diseases (e.g., asthma, sarcoidosis)

Clinical Features
  • Sudden onset of chest pain
  • Mild to moderate dyspnea
  • Rarely life-threatening
  • Severe dyspnea
  • Hypoxemia and hypercapnia
  • Chest pain
  • Potential for acute respiratory failure

Investigations
  • Chest X-ray
  • CT scan may be used for confirmation in some cases
  • Chest X-ray
  • CT scan for differential diagnosis, especially in emphysema cases

Treatment
  • Observation for small, asymptomatic cases.
  • Needle aspiration for larger cases.
  • Chest tube placement if aspiration fails.
  • Surgical options (VATS, pleurodesis) for recurrent cases.
  • Hospital admission for monitoring.
  • Chest tube placement for large or symptomatic cases.
  • Surgical intervention based on underlying disease.

Chest X-ray of Pneumothorax

CT of Pneumothorax

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a stabbing injury to the chest, having respiratory distress, 4 cm wound on the right side. On examination, his breath sounds are decreased on the right side, and he shows signs of hypoxia. His vital signs are stable. What is the most appropriate first step in managing this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform needle thoracocentesis in the 2nd intercostal space, midclavicular line

options.label: B
options.text: Insert a chest tube immediately at the site of the injury

options.label: C
options.text: Apply a sterile occlusive dressing over the wound, taped on three sides

options.label: D
options.text: Obtain a chest X-ray to assess the injury and confirm the diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: C. Apply a sterile occlusive dressing over the wound, taped on three sides
questions.explanation:
OPEN PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • Large defect in the chest wall (>3 cm).
  • Intrathoracic pressure = Atmospheric pressure.
  • If the size of the defect > 2/3rds of the trachea’s diameter, the air is drawn through the wound rather than the trachea, leading to air accumulation in the hemithorax, hypoventilation, and hypoxia.

Initial Management
  • Seal the Defect with a sterile occlusive plastic dressing (e.g., OPSITE™) taped on three sides to create a flutter valve.
  • Chest Tube Placement: Insert a chest tube as soon as possible at a site distant from the injury.

Potential Complications

Tension Pneumothorax if the defect creates a one-way valve effect.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male, after a motor vehicle accident, presents with severe respiratory distress, decreased breath sounds on the right, hyper-resonance, and tracheal deviation to the left. His BP is 85/55 mmHg, and jugular veins are distended. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Order an urgent chest X-ray to confirm the diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an immediate needle thoracocentesis in the 5th intercostal space, in anterior axillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Insert a chest tube into the 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a finger thoracostomy in the safe triangle

questions.correct_answer: B. Perform an immediate needle thoracocentesis in the 5th intercostal space, in anterior axillary line
questions.explanation:
TENSION PNEUMOTHORAX

Pathophysiology
  • D/t ‘one-way valve’ air leaks from the lung or chest wall.
  • Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any escape, collapsing and compressing the affected lung.
  • The mediastinum shifts to the opposite side, reducing venous return and compressing the opposite lung, leading to decreased cardiac output and function. This can result in sudden death.

Causes
  • Penetrating Chest Trauma.
  • Blunt Chest Trauma with parenchymal lung injury and persistent air leak.
  • Iatrogenic Lung Injury (e.g., central venepuncture)
  • Mechanical Positive-Pressure Ventilation.

Clinical Features
  • Tachypnea and Tachycardia
  • Hyper-resonance and Decreased/Absent Breath Sounds
  • Resonant Percussion with severe mediastinal/tracheal shift
  • Cyanosis and Hypotension
  • Chest Pain
  • Distended Neck Veins

Emergency Management
  • Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation.
  • Immediate Thoracocentesis (needle): Wide bore needle (typically a 20- or 22-gauge) in the 5nd intercostal space in the safety triangle.
  • Decompression should be performed in the "safe triangle."
  • Safe Triangle Boundaries:
    • Posterior: Latissimus dorsi
    • Anterior: Lateral border of the pectoralis major
    • Inferior: A line drawn perpendicularly from the nipple to the back, just anterior to the mid-axillary line.
  • In critical situations, a finger thoracostomy can be done in the same location.
  • Nasal Oxygen for support.
  • Intercostal Tube Placement (ICT) once stable and confirmed by chest X-ray.

Additional Care

  • Antibiotics and analgesics for treatment.
  • Ventilator Support with IPPV in severe cases.

questions.text: A 70 y/o woman with lung cancer presents with sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath, 3 weeks post-lobectomy. She is pale, tachypneic, with BP 85/50 mmHg and HR 120 bpm. Examination reveals right-sided dullness and diminished breath sounds. A CXR shows a large pleural effusion, and thoracentesis drains 1000ml of blood. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Observation and follow-up with chest X-ray

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate administration of intravenous fluids and blood products

options.label: C
options.text: Thoracotomy with evacuation and lung decortication

questions.explanation:
HEMOTHORAX

Definition

The presence of blood in the pleural cavity, causes irritation, pain, and potential shock.

 

Causes
  • Trauma (e.g., rib fractures)
  • Postoperative complications (e.g., lung, cardiac, esophageal surgeries)
  • Tumours (lung, mediastinum, pleura)
  • Leaking aneurysms

Clinical Features
  • Chest pain and tenderness
  • Dyspnea
  • Dullness on percussion
  • Diminished breath sounds
  • Signs of shock

Investigations
  • Chest X-ray
  • Aspiration (pleural tap)
  • Chest CT scan

Treatment
  • Intercostal chest tube (ICT) placement in the mid-axillary line in the 5th intercostal space.
  • Antibiotics and bronchodilators
  • Thoracotomy if persistent or large blood loss
    • Criteria for Thoracotomy:
      • >1.5 L blood lost in last 1 hour (or)
      • >200cc/hour over next 2-4 hours

Complications
  • Infection and empyema
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to be found in the posterior mediastinum?
questions.explanation:
Tumors of mediastinum

Anterior mediastinum

Middle mediastinum

Posterior mediastinum
  • Thymomas
  • Thymic carcinomas
  • Thymic cyst
  • Germ cell tumors
  • Lymphomas
  • Parathyroid adenomas
  • Carcinoid tumour
  • Fibroma
  • Lymphomas
  • Tumors of the heart and great vessels
  • Tumours of the trachea, mainstem bronchi, and oesophagus
  • Aortic pathologies such as aortic aneurysm, abscess, or dissection.
  • Pericardial cysts
  • Bronchogenic cysts
  • Neuroenteric cyst
  • Mesothelial cyst
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Neurilemomas (schwannomas)
  • Neurofibromas
  • Ganglioneuromas
  • Ganglioneuroblastomas
  • Neuroblastomas
  • Pheochromocytomas

questions.text: A 45 y/o male presents with chest pain and dyspnea one week after undergoing oesophagal surgery. A pleural tap reveals milky white fluid with high triglyceride levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: C. Oral diet with medium-chain triglycerides

questions.text: A 35 y/o male presents with milky urine and abdominal pain after a fatty meal. He reports weight loss and frequent urinary infections. Urinalysis shows chyluria. What is the most likely underlying cause of chyluria in this patient?

A 60 y/o male presents with fever, cough, and foul-smelling sputum. A chest X-ray reveals a localized opacity in the apical lower lobe. Sputum culture shows the presence of anaerobic bacteria. Which of the following is the most likely cause?

options.label: D
options.text: Bronchial obstruction due to lung cancer

questions.text: A 58 y/o male with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the clinic with shortness of breath and chest discomfort. A chest X-ray shows a pleural effusion on the right side. Analysis of the pleural fluid reveals the following: Pleural fluid protein to serum protein ratio: 0.7 Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) to serum LDH ratio: 0.65 Pleural fluid LDH level: 300 U/L (serum LDH upper limit of normal is 200 U/L) Based on these findings and Light’s criteria, which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pleural effusion?
questions.explanation:
Light's criteria for exudative effusions

Pleural fluid protein to serum protein ratio

> 0.5

Pleural fluid LDH to serum LDH ratio

> 0.6

Pleural fluid LDH level

> 2/3 of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH

Causes of Pleural Effusion

Transudative

Exudative
  • Congestive heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Superior vena cava obstruction
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Fluid retention/overload
  • Lobar collapse
  • Meigs syndrome
  • Malignant:
    • Lung cancer
    • Lymphoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Metastatic cancers
  • Infectious:
    • Bacterial pneumonia/empyema
    • Tuberculosis
    • Fungal infections
    • Viral infections
    • Parasitic infections
  • Collagen Vascular Disease-related:
    • Rheumatoid arthritis
    • Wegener granulomatosis
    • Systemic lupus erythematosus
    • Churg-Strauss syndrome
  • Abdominal/Gastrointestinal disease-related:
    • Esophageal perforation
    • Subphrenic abscess
    • Pancreatitis/pancreatic pseudocyst
    • Meigs syndrome
  • Other Causes:
    • Pulmonary embolism with infarction
    • Coronary artery bypass grafting
    • Radiation/trauma
    • Dressler syndrome
    • Asbestosis
    • After lung transplantation
    • After bone marrow transplantation
    • Drug-induced
    • Uremia

questions.text: A 72 y/o male with h/o COPD presents with progressive shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest X-ray findings are shown below. Thoracentesis is performed, and analysis of the pleural fluid reveals high protein & LDH levels. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Insert a chest tube for drainage

questions.correct_answer: C. Insert a chest tube for drainage

questions.text: A 50 y/o male patient has been hospitalized following a hip replacement surgery for the past 6 days. He has a history of obesity and smoking. On the sixth day, he suddenly develops shortness of breath, and chest pain, and coughs up blood. Which of the following is the most likely contributing factor to his current condition?
Which of the following is the most commonly used gold standard investigation for diagnosing pulmonary embolism in a clinical setting?
